misconceptions.inferred_category_name: No detected notional-machine misconception (code matches correct execution model)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that to right-shift an array with wrap-around, you must (1) save the last element, (2) copy each element from left neighbor to the right going backwards to avoid overwriting, then (3) put the saved last element into index 0, and finally print the array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: There is no conceptual gap here: this matches Java’s actual execution model for arrays, assignment, and loop order. The student also correctly guards against n==0, correctly uses indices, and does not display any mistaken beliefs about prompts, automatic updates, operators, parameter passing, or type conversion.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: No error; program should produce the required output for typical inputs (including n==0).
